title: 103_hr3041
content: The text chunk is about the placement of "Made in America" labels on products. Requirements for the use of "Made in America" labels include product registration with the Department of Commerce, with at least 60% of the product manufactured in the US and final assembly taking place in the US. Products must be registered within 12 months of regulations being promulgated. Penalties exist for fraudulent use of these labels. The text suggests that penalties exist for fraudulent use of "Made in America" labels, with a civil fine of up to $100,000 and the possibility of injunctive relief by the Secretary. The Secretary must establish regulations for product registration within 12 months of the Act's enactment. Definitions include "label" as any written or graphic matter on a product, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce. SEC. 2. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION TO CONSUMERS REGARDING FOREIGN CONTENT OF IMPORTED ARTICLES. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a new subsection requiring foreign articles assembled from parts of different countries to be marked with the proportion of customs value in English for US consumers. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to require foreign articles assembled from parts of different countries to be marked with the proportion of customs value for US consumers. Amendments include changes to subsections (g) and (h), with the effective date applying to articles entered after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. LABELING OF DOMESTIC PRODUCTS WITH FOREIGN PARTS. SEC. 3. LABELING OF DOMESTIC PRODUCTS WITH FOREIGN PARTS. Any product manufactured in the US with parts from a foreign country must label the country of origin and the cost proportion. Failure to comply may result in a civil fine of up to $100,000. The Secretary may seek injunctive relief to enforce compliance with labeling regulations for products with foreign parts. Regulations must be established within 12 months of the Act's enactment, with the Secretary of Commerce overseeing enforcement.
